com.biomatters.geneious.publicapi.utilities

Class DataInputOutputUtilities

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.biomatters.geneious.publicapi.utilities.DataInputOutputUtilities

  • public class DataInputOutputUtilities
extends Object
    Provides methods for reading and writing objects from DataInputStream and DataOutputStream
    Since:
    API 4.30 (Geneious 5.3.0)

    • Method Detail

      • writeUTF

        public static void writeUTF(DataOutput output,
            String string)
                     throws IOException
        Writes UTF to a DataOutput without running into the 65K limit normally encountered with DataOutput.writeUTF(String).

        When using this to serialize PluginDocument subclasses or other classes that make use of PluginDocument.FILE_DATA_ATTRIBUTE_NAME, care must be taken. See the note in the docs for writeXmlSerializable(DataOutput, XMLSerializable, ProgressListener).
        Parameters:
        output - the DataOutput to write to
        string - the string to write
        Throws:
        IOException - if an IOException was encountered when writing to output
        Since:
        API 4.30 (Geneious 5.3.0)

        Throws:

      • writeXmlSerializable

        public static void writeXmlSerializable(DataOutput out,
                        XMLSerializable xmlSerializable,
                        ProgressListener progressListener)
                                 throws IOException
        Writes an XmlSerializable object to a DataOutput which can be read back using readXmlSerializable(java.io.DataInput)

        This method lacks many of the optimizations that writeSequence(java.io.DataOutput, com.biomatters.geneious.publicapi.documents.sequence.SequenceDocument, jebl.util.ProgressListener) contains. If applicable, you should use that method instead.

        If your code wishes to invoke this on a class of XMLSerializable that makes use of PluginDocument.FILE_DATA_ATTRIBUTE_NAME (such as many PluginDocument classes, in particular SequenceDocument), In particular, that method has support for . PluginDocuments and their associated file data are generally stored using this mechanism. When creating a data file for a plugin document, code will often do so using a temporary file created via FileUtilities.createTempFile(String, boolean). Once this code has finished executing, and its resulting PluginDocument has been serialized and returned, there is no longer a java variable reference to that temporary file. This is fine for usages that immediately commit this file to a WritableDatabaseService and return the version of the file that is now in the database. However, some usages may simply pass the serialized PluginDocument straight back to calling code, which leaves the temporary file at risk of being deleted by Geneious, which now detects the file is no longer referenced.

        If the previous comment applies to your usage, and if using writeSequence() isn't possible, then you will need to keep a reference to the temporary file alive as an interned String throughout the lifetime of your Serialized object as well. As long as a String consisting of the temporary file path's value in its entirety exists in memory (for which new File(String) on that String will locate the file), Geneious will not delete that file. To assist in this, you may call getFileDataAttributeValues(Element, List) and manually manage the results from that List.
        Parameters:
        out - the DataOutput to write to.
        xmlSerializable - the XmlSerializable to write
        progressListener - for reporting progress
        Throws:
        IOException - if we can't write it.
        Since:
        API 4.714 (Geneious 7.1.4)
        See Also:
        readXmlSerializable(java.io.DataInput)

      • getFileDataAttributeValues

        public static List<String> getFileDataAttributeValues(org.jdom.Element element)
        Returns any PluginDocument.FILE_DATA_ATTRIBUTE_NAME attributeValues anywhere within the given Element's tree
        Parameters:
        element - The element
        Returns:
        A List consisting of any such attributes' values.
        Since:
        API 4.817 (Geneious 8.1.7)

      • writeBooleans

        public static int writeBooleans(DataOutputStream out,
                boolean[] values,
                int numberOfValues)
                         throws IOException
        Writes some boolean values to a stream, using 1 bit per value (rather than 1 byte per value if you use DataOutputStream.writeBoolean(boolean)
        Parameters:
        out - the stream to write to.
        values - the values to write
        numberOfValues - the number of values from the array to write
        Returns:
        the number of bytes written to the stream (which will be (numberOfValues+7)/8)
        Throws:
        IOException - if we can't write
        Since:
        API 4.40 (Geneious 5.4.0)
        See Also:
        readBooleans(java.io.DataInputStream, boolean[], int)

      • readBooleans

        public static void readBooleans(DataInputStream in,
                boolean[] values,
                int numberOfValues)
                         throws IOException
        Reads some boolean values to a stream, using 1 bit per value (rather than 1 byte per value if you use DataOutputStream.writeBoolean(boolean)
        Parameters:
        in - the stream to read from
        values - an array to read the values into
        numberOfValues - the number of values to read into the array
        Throws:
        IOException - if we can't write
        Since:
        API 4.40 (Geneious 5.4.0)
        See Also:
        writeBooleans(java.io.DataOutputStream, boolean[], int)
